data.description: Follow in the footsteps of over 250,000 emigrants who traveled to the gold fields and rich farmlands of California during the 1840s and 1850s: the greatest mass migration in American history. The California National Historic Trail is over 5,000 miles long and covers portions of 10 states. Step into history along more than 1,000 miles of ruts and traces from travelers and their overland wagons.
data.directionsInfo: Those portions of the California National Historic Trail authorized by Congress include nearly 2,000 miles of historic trail that was once the primary "road" taken by farmers, enterprising business managers, gold-seekers, and fortune hunters who chose to make a new life on the California frontier. The route passes through ten states from Missouri to California.

operatingHours.description: The California National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands, and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact individual trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: California National Historic Trail

data.description: Crater Lake inspires awe. Native Americans witnessed its formation 7,700 years ago, when a violent eruption triggered the collapse of a tall peak. Scientists marvel at its purity—fed by rain and snow, it’s the deepest lake in the USA and one of the most pristine on Earth. Artists, photographers, and sightseers gaze in wonder at its blue water and stunning setting atop the Cascade Mountain Range.

entranceFees.description: This is the summer entrance fee and is charged from mid-May through the end of October.  Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15-passenger capacity or less) and all occupants. Good for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: This is the winter entrance fee.  Admits one private, non-commercial vehicle (15-passenger capacity or less) and all occupants. Good for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Private Vehicle

entranceFees.description: Admits one or two passengers on a private, non-commercial motorcycle. Good for 7 days. Summer rate from mid-May to October 31st.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one or two passengers on a private, non-commercial motorcycle. Good for 7 days. Winter rate from 11/1 through mid-May.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Motorcycle

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual with no motor vehicle (bicyclist, hiker, pedestrian). Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge. Good for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entranceFees.description: Admits one individual on a snowmobile for travel on snow covered North Entrance Road closed to regular vehicle traffic. Youth 15 and under are admitted free of charge. Good for 7 days.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Snowmobile

entranceFees.description: Fees for commercial vehicles are based on the capacity of the vehicle, not the number of passengers on board.  In addition to the $25 per vehicle there is also a $15 per passenger charge.
entranceFees.title: Commercial Entrance - Sedan

entranceFees.description: Fees for commercial vehicles are based on the capacity of the vehicle, not the number of passengers on board.

entrancePasses.description: If you visit twice in 12 months purchasing the park's annual pass will save you money. It is valid at Crater Lake National Park as well as Lava Beds National Monument, Lassen Volcanic National Park, and Whiskeytown National Recreation Area. This annual pass costs $55 and admits the pass owner and all accompanying passengers in a single, private, noncommercial vehicle (or the pass owner plus up to three people when entry is by other means).
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From the west (Medford) - Take Hwy 62 to the West Entrance. Open year-round. From the south (Klamath Falls) - Take Hwy 97 north to Hwy 62 to the South Entrance. Open year-round. The North Entrance is on Hwy 138 and is accessed from Interstate 5 east at Roseburg or Hwy 97 south from Bend and Chemult. Winter travelers from Roseburg take Route 138 east to Route 230 south to Route 62 east to the park's west entrance. Travelers from Bend take Route 97 south to Route 62 to the park's south entrance.

operatingHours.description: Crater Lake National Park is open year-round, 24 hours a day. Some roads, trails, and facilities, however, are closed seasonally due to snow. North Entrance Road, and West and East Rim Drives close for the season on November 1 (or earlier if there is significant snowfall). Crews begin removing snow from these roads in April, but opening dates vary. The North Entrance Road and West Rim Drive tend to open in early June. The East Rim Drive typically opens in early July.
operatingHours.name: Crater Lake National Park

operatingHours.description: The park's West Entrance on Oregon Highway 62 is open year round.
operatingHours.name: West Entrance

operatingHours.description: The park's South Entrance on Oregon Highway 62 is open year round.
operatingHours.name: South Entrance

operatingHours.description: The park's North Entrance, off of Oregon Highway 138, is usually open from June through October. It is closed in the winter due to snow. Opening dates vary each year depending on snowfall and road conditions.
operatingHours.name: North Entrance

data.weatherInfo: July, August, and September are your best bets for warm, dry weather. In May, June, and October, sunny days alternate with periods of rain and snow. Winters at Crater Lake are long and snowy. Storms from the Pacific Ocean dump an annual average of 41 feet (13.5 meters) of snow at park headquarters. When it's raining or snowing, the lake is usually hidden by clouds. Crater Lake is completely invisible about 50% of the time in the winter!
data.name: Crater Lake

data.description: Located on the north bank of the Columbia River, in sight of snowy mountain peaks and a vibrant urban landscape, this park has a rich cultural past. From a frontier fur trading post, to a powerful military legacy, the magic of flight, and the origin of the American Pacific Northwest, history is shared at four unique sites. Discover stories of transition, settlement, conflict, and community.

entranceFees.description: Day use/entrance fees are required for visitors ages 16 and up to access reconstructed Fort Vancouver. Federal Interagency Passes are accepted. There is no day use/entrance fee for visitors accessing the Visitor Center, Pearson Air Museum, the Barclay House, and McLoughlin House.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: Fort Vancouver National Historic Site offers an annual pass that covers entrance fees for 4 visitors ages 16 and up. Visitors ages 15 and under are free. This pass can be purchased at the gates of Fort Vancouver or at Recreation.gov.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. Turn south onto Fort Vancouver Way. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center. From I-205, go west on Highway 14 about six miles, then take I-5 north. From I-5, take the Mill Plain Boulevard exit (Exit 1-C) and head east. At the traffic circle, go east on Evergreen Boulevard and follow signs to the Fort Vancouver Visitor Center.

exceptions.name: New Year's Eve & New Year's Day

operatingHours.description: Standard operating hours for Vancouver, Washington facilities are Tuesday through Saturday, 9:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m.

operatingHours.description: The Oregon City, Oregon facilities are open Fridays and Saturdays from 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m. With the exception of its winter seasonal closure.
operatingHours.name: Oregon City, Oregon

data.name: Fort Vancouver

data.fullName: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail
data.description: At the end of the last Ice Age, 18,000 to 15,000 years ago, an ice dam in northern Idaho created Glacial Lake Missoula stretching 3,000 square miles around Missoula, Montana. The dam burst and released flood waters across Washington, down the Columbia River into Oregon before reaching the Pacific Ocean. The Ice Age Floods forever changed the lives and landscape of the Pacific Northwest.
data.directionsInfo: To Trail Headquarters from Spokane Take I-90 West At Exit 277, merge onto US-2 toward Davenport/Fairchild AFB/Spokane Airport Just past Wilbur, turn right onto WA-21 Stay left onto Highway 174 Turn right onto WA-155 Stay on WA-155 past Grand Coulee Dam and into the town of Coulee Dam Cross the Columbia River and continue on WA-155 Turn right onto Crest Drive and follow up the hill. The HQ Office is located on the left

operatingHours.description: The Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail is a collection of sites operated and owned by a variety of partners. , Hours of operation and season will vary from site to site. Please check each respective site for more details and information.
operatingHours.name: Ice Age Floods National Geologic Trail

data.fullName: John Day Fossil Beds National Monument
data.description: Large rhino-like brontotheres roam a semitropical forest. Dog-sized, three-toed horses dart between the trees. The cat-like nimravid and bear dogs stalk their prey. The climate cools and forests alter to dryer grasslands. Saber tooth cats and camels get replaced by mountain lions and deer. Paleontologists learn more about the ancient animals and environment with every new fossil they discover.
data.directionsInfo: John Day Fossil Beds encompasses 14,000 acres in three geographically separated units in Oregon: Sheep Rock Unit, Painted Hills Unit, and Clarno Unit. The Sheep Rock Unit is located between the towns of Dayville and Kimberly. The Painted Hills Unit is located 9 miles northwest of of the town of Mitchell. The Clarno Unit is located on Highway 218 twenty miles west of the town of Fossil.

operatingHours.description: All outdoor recreation opportunities in the park are open daily, including all overlooks and hiking trails at the park’s three units: Sheep Rock, Painted Hills, and Clarno.
operatingHours.name: Outdoor Recreation Areas

data.weatherInfo: Weather conditions at John Day Fossil Beds National Monument are highly variable in this semi-arid desert landscape. Summer highs can climb into the 110's. Winters tend to be fairly mild, with occassional snow and ice and lows occasionally dipping into the single digits.
data.name: John Day Fossil Beds

data.description: The Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail winds nearly 4,900 miles through the homelands of more than 60 Tribal nations. It follows the historic outbound and inbound routes of the Lewis and Clark Expedition of 1803-1806 from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania to the Pacific Ocean. Follow the trail to find the people, places, and stories that make up the complex legacy of the expedition.
data.directionsInfo: Lewis & Clark National Historic Trail Headquarters Visitor Center is located inside DOI, National Park Service, Interior Region 3,4,5 Office. We are right on the Missouri River next to the Bob Kerrey Pedestrian Bridge in downtown Omaha, NE.

operatingHours.description: Lewis and Clark National Historic Trail Visitor Center is located on the Missouri River in Omaha, Nebraska.
operatingHours.name: Visitor Center Hours

data.weatherInfo: In winter, watch for ice on trails and sidewalks. In summer, make sure to drink plenty of water and wear sunscreen on hot days. Keep in mind the Trail covers 16 states, use www.weather.gov to look up the specific area you plan to visit.
data.name: Lewis & Clark

data.fullName: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
data.description: Explore the timeless rainforests and majestic coastal vistas. Discover the rich heritage of the native people. Unfold the dramatic stories of America's most famous explorers. The park encompasses sites along the Columbia River and the Pacific Coast. Follow in the footsteps of the explorers and have an adventure in history.

entranceFees.description: Entrance fees are collected at the Fort Clatsop Visitor Center.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: The annual Oregon Coast Passport covers entry, vehicle parking, and day use fees at all Oregon state and federal fee sites along the Oregon Coast. Valid for 12 months.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: The main site of Fort Clatsop is located south of Astoria just over Youngs Bay, east of the town of Warrenton, and approximately 14 miles north of Seaside. Our satellite sites include: Netul Landing, located 1.25 miles south of the main Fort Clatsop site. Middle Village, located on the 101 left off the Astoria-Megler Bridge. Dismal Nitch, located on the 401 right off the Astoria-Megler Bridge. The Salt Works, located off the Lewis and Clark Way in Seaside, Oregon. Keep an eye out for brown signs.

operatingHours.description:
Winter Hours:
Begin the day after Labor Day
Open 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Fort Clatsop Visitor Center and Replica (Winter)

addresses.line1: Lewis and Clark National Historical Park
Lewis and Clark National Historical Park

images.title: Fort Clatsop
images.altText: A fifty foot square wooden fort surrounded by tall trees in a forest.
images.caption: The second replica of Fort Clatsop is the main attraction at Lewis and Clark National Historical Park

images.title: Fort Clatsop Visitor Center and Sign
images.altText: A wooden rectangular sign reading Fort Clatsop eclipsing a wide one story building and flag pole
images.caption: The entrance sign and Fort Clatsop visitor center marks the main entrance point to the replica of Fort Clatsop itself.

images.title: Fort Clatsop Main Entrance Sign
images.altText: A wooden sign standing as a tall rectangle, the words Fort Clatsop carved of wood placed on it.
images.caption: The entrance sign at the Visitor Center was created in a style that reflects the actual Fort itself, wooden stakes and all.

images.title: Netul River Trail Bridge
images.altText: Looking directly down a short railed bridge towards a calm river surrounded by leafless trees.
images.caption: The Netul River Trail follows 1.25 miles of river and crosses over inlets that salmon and other fish rest at.

images.title: Canoe Bow on the Netul River
images.altText: The front end of a canoe on a river, the water still and reflecting large trees and clouds.
images.caption: Paddling on the Lewis and Clark River allows visitors to experience the site from an entirely different perspective, the tidal influenced waters are often gentle and serene.

images.title: Kayaks from Otter Point
images.altText: Paddlers in warm-colored kayaks cluster along the grassy banks of a river's side channel.
images.caption: Every summer, rangers accompany dozens of visitors on paddle tours of the Lewis and Clark River.

data.weatherInfo: We see an average of 70 inches of rain a year and we are the foggiest location in the Lower 48 states. Summer months are usually nice with days ranging from 55-70 degrees. Winters are wet and mild, usually 40-55 degrees. During the 106 days the Lewis and Clark Expedition wintered at Fort Clatsop in 1806 it rained all but 12 days and they saw the sun 6 times. While we are usually not so dreary make sure to prepare for rain or shine.
data.name: Lewis and Clark

data.description: Since time immemorial, the valleys, prairies, mountains, and plateaus of the inland northwest have been home to the nimíipuu (Nez Perce) people. Extremely resilient, they survived the settling of the United States and adapted to a changed world. Nez Perce National Historical Park consists of 38 places important to the history and culture of the nimíipuu. Explore these places. Learn their stories.
data.directionsInfo: Driving south bound on U.S. Highway 95 you will find the Visitor Center 10 miles from Lewiston, ID. Roughly one mile after crossing the Clearwater River you will find the park entrance on your left. When driving north on U.S. Highway 95 the Visitor Center will be 3 miles north of Lapwai, ID. The park entrance will be on your right.

operatingHours.description: Summer visitor center operating hours are 8:30 am - 4:00 pm daily. In the winter, the visitor center is open 5-days a week from Tuesday - Saturday from 8:30 am - 4:00 pm.  Closed Sunday and Monday.  The visitor center is closed Thanksgiving, Christmas, and New Year's days.
operatingHours.name: Nez Perce National Historical Park, Spalding Visitor Center

images.title: Painted Tipi
images.altText: Colorful painted tipi on green lawn
images.caption: Every morning in the summer Rangers put a tipi on the front lawn of the visitor center. Visitors are always welcome to help.

images.title: Buffalo Eddy
images.altText: Petroglyph carvings on the bank of the Snake River.
images.caption: Buffalo Eddy contains many petroglyphs and is considered a ancient crossing place.

images.title: Take Flight
images.altText: Birds in flight across a grassy field.
images.caption: Birds take flight across a grassy field.

images.title: Buffalo Hide Tipi
images.altText: Elder (Mylie Lawyer) sitting in front of Old Buffalo hide tipi.
images.caption: The only known remaining complete buffalo hide tipi belonging to a Nez Perce.

images.title: Appaloosa Horse Parade
images.altText: Horses and riders dressed in native regalia.
images.caption: This horse parade was held in the Spalding picnic area during the parks 50th anniversary in 2015.

images.title: Weippe Camas
images.altText: Blue Camas flowers in a prairie field.
images.caption: Camas has been a food staple of the Nez Perce for thousands of years.

data.weatherInfo: Elevations in the Park range from 700 feet above sea level to over 8,000, providing a wide range of climatic conditions, that follow the four seasons. Be prepared for very warm weather in the summer months, in particular in the river valleys. The spring and fall are moderate and comfortable. Winter conditions can be severe in the higher elevations, with snow and ice making travel difficult and dangerous. Please visit the National Weather Service for comprehensive weather information.
data.name: Nez Perce

data.description: Deep within the Siskiyou Mountains are dark, twisting passages that await your discovery. Eons of acidic water seeping into marble rock created and decorated the wondrous “Marble Halls of Oregon.” Join a tour, get a taste of what caving is all about, and explore a mountain from the inside and out!
data.directionsInfo: Take 199 to Cave Junction, Oregon. Turn onto OR-46 (a Chevron gas station is on the corner). Follow OR-46 for 20 miles to the Monument and Preserve.

operatingHours.description:
Cave tours are suspended at this time. We do not have a current opening date but hope to resume by late spring. Please continue to check this website for updates. We apologize for any inconvenience this may cause.

Please call our Illinois Valley Visitor Center at 541-592-5125 if you have any questions.
operatingHours.name: Spring hours

operatingHours.description:
Cave tours are available daily through the fall of 2025. Guided tours are offered 10:00 AM – 4:00 PM. 

Reservations for tours will be available at www.recreation.gov.

Same day, first come, first served tickets are also available at both park visitor centers.
operatingHours.name: Summer Hours

operatingHours.description:
Cave tours will be available from 10:00 am to 4:00 pm daily through Sunday, November 2, 2025.

Please call our Illinois Valley Visitor Center at 541-592-5125 if you have any questions.

Closed in the winter.
operatingHours.name: Fall Hours

data.description: Imagine yourself an emigrant headed for Oregon: would promises of lush farmlands and a new beginning lure you to leave home and walk for weeks? More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states and serve as reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.
data.directionsInfo: More than 2,000 miles of trail ruts and traces can still be seen along the Oregon National Historic Trail in six states- reminders of the sacrifices, struggles, and triumphs of early American settlers.

operatingHours.description: The Oregon National Historic Trail is not a clearly marked hiking trail. Instead it is a corridor that passes through communities, urban areas, public lands and Wilderness. The route travels across a variety of land ownerships and management, including private land. Each location varies as to the hours of operation and access. Please contact trail sites before your visit for more information.
operatingHours.name: Oregon National Historic Trail
